BodyCopy.p: Mark Twain (but also attributed to Gideon Tucker) is quoted as having said, "No man's life, liberty or property are safe while the Legislature is in session." This will be especially true when Congress convenes in the new year and considers tax reform. Tax reform was a hot topic during the recent election, and the Republican majority in the House of Representatives is already gearing up to advance some significant changes in Federal tax law.
One outcome of tax reform is there are almost always winners and losers. What impact might tax reform have on captives? Will tax reform have no impact on captives, or will they be winners or losers?
Rather than speculate on what the impact might be, here are three recommendations to all those working in the captive insurance industry or interested in the future of it.

li.p: Take the time to understand the tax reform process.
Be proactive in supporting the advocacy efforts of Captive Insurance Companies Association, the Self-Insurance Institute of America, and your state captive association.
Communicate with your US congressman and senator.

BodyCopy.p: To help with the first step in understanding the tax reform process, read Understanding the Tax Reform Process: FAQ, which KPMG published December 5, 2016. It is a great primer that will provide readers with an understanding of the following.

li.p: The substance of tax reform and other useful insights

BodyCopy.p: The US Constitution requires that all bills regarding taxation must originate in the House of Representatives. The House Committee on Ways and Means is the chief tax-writing committee, and House procedure is that all bills regarding taxation must go through this committee. For that reason, communications with persons serving on that committee are especially important when taxation or revenue measures are under consideration. The chairman of that committee is Rep. Kevin Brady, a Republican from Texas's 8th District. The ranking member of the Democrats is Rep. Sander Levin, representing Michigan's 9th District. A complete listing of members of the Ways and Means Committee can be found on the committee website.

It is worth ending this article by repeating Mr. Twain's (or Mr. Tucker's) quote, "No man's life, liberty or property are safe while the Legislature is in session." Be prepared to understand the process and what, if any effects, tax reform proposals will have on captives.
